document_info.title: Amiri Decree No. (2) of 2017 Issuing the Real Estate Tenancy Law in the Emirate of Ajman
document_info.issuer: Humaid bin Rashid Al Nuaimi, Ruler of the Emirate of Ajman
document_info.source_jurisdiction: United Arab Emirates - Emirate of Ajman

preamble: We, Humaid bin Rashid Al Nuaimi, Member of the Supreme Council, Ruler of the Emirate of Ajman, After perusal of the provisions of Articles 21, 122, 149, and 151 of the Constitution of the State... And perusal of the provisions of Federal Law No. (3) of 1983 regarding the Federal Judicial Authority and the laws amending it; And the provisions of Federal Law No. (5) of 1985 issuing the Civil Transactions Law, and the laws amending it; And the provisions of Federal Law No. (11) of 1992 issuing the Civil Procedure Law in the State; And perusal of the provisions of Amiri Decree No. (3) of 2009, issuing the Amended Real Estate Tenancy Law in the Emirate of Ajman, as amended by Amiri Decree No. (8) of 2014... and by Decree No. (3) of 2016; And perusal of the Resolution of His Excellency the Minister of Justice No. (18) of 2016 regarding the deputation of judges from the Ministry of Justice to preside over the chambers of the Rent Disputes Settlement Committee in the Emirate of Ajman, in addition to their original duties at the Ajman Federal Court of First Instance; And to keep pace with the significant growth witnessed by the Emirate in recent years in the field of real estate investments and land development, through the construction of various buildings thereon, for the purpose of leasing them for residential, commercial, and industrial purposes, and for practicing professional and vocational activities, and the consequent steady increase in the number of real estate tenancy disputes in the Emirate; And based on the recommendations of the Chairman of the Executive Council, after consultation with the Chairman of the Rent Disputes Committee and with the relevant local authorities in the Emirate, regarding the need to make certain amendments to the currently applicable Real Estate Tenancy Law, which have become required to enable the Rent Disputes Committee in the Emirate to perform its duties smoothly and effectively despite the steady increase in the number of rental disputes, and in a manner that ensures the realization of our desire to settle and resolve tenancy disputes in the Emirate through decisions issued by the said Committee, under the supervision of its judges, having legal authority as legal, final, and decisive decisions, and executed effectively and in the shortest time by the judges in the Committee without the need to refer them to the competent civil court in the Emirate, thereby achieving swift justice and stability in the leased real estate sector and the interests of lessors and lessees of real estate in the Emirate in support of sustainable development therein; And whereas we deemed it in the public interest... We have decided to issue the Amiri Decree, the text of which follows:

Article_1.title: Name of the Decree
Article_1.content: This Decree shall be named "Amiri Decree No. (2) of 2017 Issuing the Real Estate Tenancy Law in the Emirate of Ajman" and it shall come into force and be deemed effective as of the fifteenth day of January 2017.

Article_2.title: Definitions and Interpretations
Article_2.content:
In this Decree, unless the context of the text requires a different meaning, the words and phrases below shall have the meanings assigned opposite each of them as follows:

"The Ruler": Means the Ruler of the Emirate of Ajman.
"The Executive Council": Means the Executive Council of the Emirate of Ajman.
"The Municipality": Means the Municipality and Planning Department in Ajman or any branch thereof within whose jurisdiction the Leased Property subject to the provisions of this Decree is located.
"Government Entity": Means any department, institution, authority, administration, or other facility affiliated with the Government of the Emirate, or established by Amiri Decree, or reorganized, explicitly considering its properties as public funds.
"The Disputes Committee": Means the Committee formed pursuant to Article (15) of this Decree to undertake the tasks of hearing and deciding, decisively and finally, disputes arising between lessors and lessees of real estate in the Emirate of Ajman in accordance with its competencies under Article (16) of this Decree.
"Execution Judge": Means any judge deputized from the Ministry of Justice and assigned by the Chairman of the Disputes Committee to execute decisions issued by the Disputes Committee.
"Person": Means any natural or legal person, private or public.
"Leased Property": Subject to the provisions of Article (3(2)), means any plot of land or building, of whatever type, shape, or components, the possession of which is agreed to be transferred from its owner to a lessee under a lease contract for the latter to utilize for residential purposes or for any commercial or industrial purpose or to use as an office or offices for practicing any profession or craft or any other activities.
"The Lessor": For the purposes of this Decree, includes:
(a) The person who legally owns the Leased Property, or any undivided share therein, and the word also includes the person to whom the ownership of the Leased Property is transferred, in whole or in part, during the term of its lease; or
(b) The legal heirs of a natural Lessor in the event of his death, or the legal successors of a legal person in the event of its liquidation;
(c) The Lessor's agent duly authorized to dispose of the Leased Property; or
(d) The employee duly authorized to dispose of real estate belonging to the concerned Government Entity or any other corporate entity; or
(e) Any real estate leasing office licensed in the Emirate to practice real estate leasing activities, whether the properties are owned by the owner of that office or in his capacity as an investor in such properties or in his capacity as an agent for the Lessor; or
(f) The person who holds, pursuant to a lease contract duly concluded with the Lessor, the right to re-lease that property or sublease it to others, whether in whole or in part.
"Lessor's Agent": Means the person authorized by the Lessor pursuant to a legal power of attorney issued by the Lessor, and the phrase also includes the customary agent.
"The Lessee": Means the person who occupies the Leased Property pursuant to a lease contract concluded with the Lessor, and the word also includes the Lessee's family members residing with him, and any Sub-lessee to whom possession of the Leased Property is legally transferred from the original Lessee.
"Sub-lessee": Means the person who occupies, by way of sublease, a property or part of a property leased from the original Lessor to another lessee.
"Lease Contract": Means the written contract concluded between the lessor of the property and its lessee as described in Article (4) of this Decree, whereby the lessor of the property is obligated to enable the Lessee to possess the Leased Property and obtain the intended benefit from it for a specific period in return for a known Rent Amount.
"Rent Amount": Means the cash consideration of a specific amount agreed upon between the Lessor and the Lessee in return for the lease of the Leased Property for a specific period, and this includes any increase in the Rent Amount decided in accordance with the provisions of Article (6(5)) or Article (6(6)) of this Decree.
"Notification": Means the written notice or warning sent by either party to the Lease Contract to the other party via the Notary Public, or by registered mail, or for hand delivery, or by any other means of correspondence approved by the Disputes Committee.
"Executive Regulations": Means the regulations regulating the work of the Disputes Committee, issued by the Chairman of the Executive Council, after consultation with the Chairman of the Disputes Committee, in accordance with the provisions of Article 17(4) of this Decree.

Article_3.title: Scope of Application of the Decree
Article_3.content:
3(1) The provisions of this Decree shall apply to Leased Properties designated for residential, commercial, industrial, or any other similar purpose, or for practicing any profession, craft, or other activities, located within the boundaries of the city of Ajman, including properties within free zones or within any other area in the Emirate of Ajman to which the Ruler decides from time to time to apply the provisions of this Decree, provided that the tenancy relationship between the Lessor and the Lessee:
(a) Began prior to the effective date of this Decree, but its term has not expired by its effective date; or
(b) Began prior to the effective date of this Decree and the parties thereto have renewed it, or it is hoped that the parties thereto will renew it, in accordance with the provisions of this Decree; or
(c) Its term expired prior to the effective date of this Decree, but the Lessee remained occupying the Leased Property until the effective date of this Decree.
(d) Will begin at any time after the effective date of this Decree.

3(2) The provisions of this Decree shall not apply to:
(a) Agricultural lands and buildings erected thereon.
(b) Housing provided by building owners for the accommodation of guards residing in those buildings.
(c) Buildings or labor complexes provided by companies or commercial or industrial establishments for the accommodation of their workers without charging them rent.
(d) Rooms and suites inside hotels or furnished hotel apartments.
(e) Places equipped as restaurants, cafeterias, cafes, barber or beauty salons, and shops and stores used for selling any goods, when such places and shops are owned by the concerned hotels and furnished hotel apartments and they lease them to others to operate within the buildings of the concerned hotels and furnished hotel apartments under the supervision of the hotel management or the concerned furnished apartments management.
(f) Wedding and event halls and places equipped as restaurants, cafeterias, cafes, or barber or beauty salons owned by public benefit associations and utilized to serve their members or customers.
(g) Shops and temporary gaming and entertainment places established within the activities of festivals and public events in the Emirate.
(h) Lands leased under lease/investment contracts for a period of eight (8) years or more for the purpose of investment by erecting buildings thereon, at the request of the Lessee and according to his specifications, for the Lessee to utilize those buildings throughout the term of the concerned lease/investment contract.

Article_4.title: Lease Contract
Article_4.content:
4(1) No real estate may be leased for residential purposes, or for any commercial or industrial purpose, or for use as an office for practicing any profession or freelance work except by virtue of a Lease Contract drawn up on the form approved by the Municipality. The Lessor must attest the Lease Contract at the Municipality and pay the prescribed attestation fees, or ensure that the Lessee attests and pays the same, within a maximum period of twenty-one (21) days after the signing of the concerned Lease Contract by the Lessor and the Lessee. In the event of failure to attest the Lease Contract, the Lessor shall be punished with a fine equal to three times the prescribed attestation fees for the concerned Lease Contract. Every renewal of the Lease Contract term shall be treated as a new Lease Contract that must be attested and the prescribed fees paid thereon in the same manner stipulated above.

4(2) The Lease Contract, attested by the Municipality in the manner referred to in Clause (4(1)) above, shall have the force of an official instrument regarding the contents of that contract, and shall be legally accepted for compulsory execution in accordance with the provisions of the Civil Procedure Law applicable in the State.

4(3) The special conditions recorded in the Lease Contract concluded between the Lessor and the Lessee shall be read and interpreted as an integral part of the Lease Contract and binding on both parties unless the Disputes Committee decides, upon the request of any party, that those special conditions, or any of them, are unfair and contrary to the provisions of this Decree or the prevailing customs in real estate leasing in the Emirate.

4(4) Government departments and institutions in the Emirate, both local and federal, may not accept any real estate Lease Contract in the Emirate of Ajman in any transaction whatsoever unless that contract is attested by the Municipality in the manner described in Clauses (4(1)) or (4(2)) above. Notwithstanding the foregoing, if the Lessee continues to occupy the Leased Property without renewing the contract term with a new Lease Contract as aforementioned, for any reason whatsoever, or in the event of loss or damage to the original or renewed Lease Contract, then every interested party may obtain an official certificate from the Municipality regarding the concerned Lease Contract after paying the prescribed fees to the Municipality for such certificate. Such certificate shall have the force of an official instrument regarding the data contained therein. The issuance of such certificate does not exempt the Lessor from his obligations to attest the Lease Contract in accordance with the provisions of Article 4(1) above.

Article_5.title: Lease Term
Article_5.content:
5(1) The lease term must be specified and agreed upon between the parties. If such term is not explicitly specified in the Lease Contract, the Lease Contract shall be deemed concluded for one year.

5(2) If the Lease Contract includes a specific term, the Lease Contract may not be terminated during its valid term mentioned therein except by mutual consent, or in accordance with the provisions of Article (5(5)) or the provisions of Article (12) of this Decree, as the case may be. If the contract term expires and the Lessee remains utilizing the Leased Property without a written demand from the Lessor to the Lessee to vacate the property in accordance with the provisions of Article (12) of this Decree, and provided the Lessee pays the Rent Amount at the time prescribed for payment, then the Lease Contract shall be implicitly and automatically renewed with the same conditions applicable at that time for an additional year, even if a new Lease Contract is not signed between the Lessor and the Lessee. Such renewal of the contract term is without prejudice to the right of the Municipality to collect the prescribed annual fees from the Lessor for attesting the renewed Lease Contract.

5(3) Subject to the provisions of Articles (9(5)) and (9(6)) of this Decree, the term of a Sublease contract issued by the original Lessee to a Sub-lessee shall expire upon the expiry of the term of the original Lease Contract unless the original Lessor agrees in writing to extend the term of the Sublease contract.

5(4) The Lessee shall not be prejudiced by the transfer of ownership of the Leased Property to a new owner, or by the death of the Lessor if he is a natural person, or by his dissolution and liquidation if he is a legal person. The new Lessor may not demand the eviction of the Lessee from the Leased Property or increase his Rent Amount except only in accordance with the provisions of this Decree. However, the heirs of the Lessee may terminate the tenancy relationship on the date agreed upon for the end of the contract term, or within a maximum period of sixty days from the date of the death of their testator, whichever is earlier. In this case, the new Lessor is entitled to collect the Rent Amount from the Lessee until the date on which the actual eviction takes place.

5(5) If the Lease Contract contains a specific term, the Lessee may not terminate the contract before the expiry of its term unless he gives the Lessor notice of his desire to terminate the contract two months prior to the date intended for his vacating of the Leased Property and agrees to pay an amount to the Lessor equivalent to two months' rent. In the event of failure to give such notice, the Lessee shall remain legally obligated to pay, and may be claimed at any subsequent time to pay, the Rent Amount to the Lessor until the date the Lessor receives the concerned Leased Property, even if it is proven that it was actually vacated by the Lessee before the date of the Lessor's receipt thereof.

5(6) The Lessee shall not be exempted from paying the Rent Amount in the event a lawsuit is filed by any party against the other party, throughout the duration of hearing the lawsuit and the issuance of the judgment therein and its execution, as long as the Lessee remains occupying the concerned property.

Article_6.title: Rent Amount
Article_6.content:
6(1) The parties to the Lease Contract must specify the amount of the Rent Amount within the conditions of the Lease Contract. The Rent Amount becomes due on the Lessee upon his utilization of the benefit of the Leased Property or upon his ability to utilize it, including the right to use the facilities of the Leased Property such as swimming pools, gyms, health clubs, and car parks, unless the contract explicitly stipulates otherwise.

6(2) The parties to the Lease Contract may agree to accelerate the payment of the Rent Amount, or defer it, or pay it in installments payable at specific times explicitly determined in the Lease Contract. If there is no agreement regarding such installments, or if it is impossible to prove their due dates to the Lessor, then the Rent Amount must be paid in four installments of equal value.

6(3) If the parties neglect to specify the amount of the Rent Amount in the Lease Contract, and it is impossible to prove the amount of the Rent Amount by customary legal evidence, then the Lessor shall be entitled to the "Rent of Similar" (Market Rent) determined by the Disputes Committee for the Leased Property. When determining the "Rent of Similar," the Disputes Committee shall take into consideration the conditions of the leased real estate market in the Emirate, including construction and maintenance costs at the time of the dispute, or the average amount of rent for three properties in the area of the concerned Leased Property that are approximately similar in condition and age to the Leased Property subject of the dispute, in addition to any other standards, circumstances, or factors as the Disputes Committee may deem appropriate to consider for the purpose of reaching a sound and reasonable decision regarding the determination of the "Rent of Similar" subject of the dispute.

6(4) If the contract term is extended implicitly and automatically by operation of law in accordance with the provisions of Article (5(2)) of this Decree, the Lessor shall be entitled to the Rent Amount that was applicable immediately prior to the extension term, and it shall continue to apply for one year from the date of expiry of the original Lease Contract term, unless the Disputes Committee decides on a longer period as it may deem appropriate.

6(5) If the Lessee discovers, after signing the Lease Contract, that the Rent Amount mentioned in the Lease Contract exceeds, exorbitantly, the rent amounts mentioned in lease contracts for properties similar to his Leased Property located in the same building or in the area of the Leased Property, and that the said lease contracts were concluded during the last three (3) months immediately preceding the date of his contract, then the Lessee may file a complaint with the Disputes Committee requesting a reduction of the Rent Amount mentioned in the Lease Contract to be equal to the "Rent of Similar" for similar properties in the same building or in the area of the Leased Property subject of the dispute. In this case, the Disputes Committee may, by a decision it issues—provided it is based on reasonable justifications—determine the "Rent of Similar" and oblige the Lessor to it, and exempt the Lessee from paying any increase in the Rent Amount imposed on him by the Lessor in the Lease Contract without legitimate justification.

6(6) Subject to the provisions of Article (6(7)) below, the Lessor may not increase the amount of the Rent Amount mentioned in the Lease Contract signed by him except after the lapse of three (3) full years from the commencement date of the Lease Contract, or from the date of the last increase imposed by the Lessor on the Rent Amount mentioned in the Lease Contract, whichever date is later. The Lessee who commits to paying the new Rent Amount on its due dates has the right to continue occupying the Leased Property and utilizing the benefit thereof, under the same conditions of the Lease Contract signed by the parties, throughout the said three (3) years, whether a new Lease Contract is signed or not.

6(7) The Lessor may increase the Rent Amount mentioned in the Lease Contract after the expiry of the three years mentioned in Article (6(6)) above, subject to two conditions:
(1) That he sends a written notice delivered to the Lessee at least two months before the expiry date of the current Lease Contract; and
(2) That the increase does not exceed twenty percent (20%) of the Rent Amount applicable at the time of the said notice. If the two mentioned conditions are met, the Lessee may not object to such increase.

6(8) Notwithstanding the provision of Article (6(6)), the Lessor may request the Disputes Committee to increase the Rent Amount by a percentage higher than twenty percent (20%) of the applicable Rent Amount at the concerned time. However, for the Lessor's request for the increase to be granted, it is required:
(a) That a full year has elapsed from the effective date of the concerned Lease Contract, or from the date of the last increase in the Rent Amount, as the case may be; and
(b) That the Lessor has actually performed improvements or maintenance works of high cost in the Leased Property before the date of his request to increase the rent, or otherwise, that the Lessor's request for the required increase is based on legally acceptable evidence confirming the occurrence of significant increases in real estate prices in the Emirate or in construction and maintenance costs, or that the request is based on any other economic justifications that satisfy the Disputes Committee; and
(c) That the Lessor has notified the Lessee in writing of the increase three (3) months before the expiry date of the lease term applicable at that time, and the Lessee remained in possession of the Leased Property without a written objection from him to the required increase delivered to the Lessor within seven (7) days from the date of his receipt of the Lessor's notice of increase. Such objection shall not be considered unless the Lessee delivers a copy thereof, within the said seven (7) days, to the Rapporteur of the Disputes Committee. In the event the Lessee objects to the increase, he must file a lawsuit with the Disputes Committee to determine the amount of increase in the Rent Amount applicable at that time. The Disputes Committee shall decide on the lawsuit after taking into consideration the circumstances, factors, and standards mentioned in Article 6(3) above.

6(9) If the Lessor increases the Rent Amount by a percentage higher than 20% without fulfilling the requirements of Article 6(6) and Article (6(7)), or if he does not comply with the decision of the Disputes Committee to correct this violation, the Disputes Committee may impose on the violating Lessor a fine of not less than five thousand (5,000) Dirhams and not exceeding twenty thousand (20,000) Dirhams.

Article_7.title: Lessor's Guarantees for the Leased Property
Article_7.content:
7(1) Once the Rent Amount, or the accelerated part thereof, is paid, the Lessee has the right to utilize the Leased Property fully and without hindrance impeding its utilization. The Lessee has, in particular, the right to possess the Leased Property in quiet and continuous possession until the lease term agreed upon in the Lease Contract expires.

7(2) The Lessor must maintain the property as stated in Article (8) of this Decree, unless the parties have explicitly agreed otherwise in the Lease Contract.

7(3) The Lessor may not cause any damage or change to the Leased Property that prevents the Lessee from fully utilizing the Leased Property in the required manner in accordance with the provisions of this Decree.

7(4) The Lessor may not, whether personally or through others, cut off electricity, water, telephone, or any other similar services from the Leased Property, or remove, destroy, or disable any of the features or benefits that were available in the Leased Property at the time of its lease, or perform any other act intended to deprive the Lessee of the full enjoyment of the benefits of the Leased Property, or intended to force the Lessee to vacate the property or accept any increase in the Rent Amount contrary to the provisions of this Decree and the provisions of the Lease Contract. In the event of any act by the Lessor in violation of the foregoing, the Lessee has the right to submit an urgent request to the Chairman of the Disputes Committee for redress. In this case, the Chairman of the Disputes Committee must, on behalf of the Disputes Committee and in the shortest possible time, issue his order in writing to the Lessor or to any concerned official entity in the Emirate, including the Police, the Municipality, and the Electricity, Water, and Telecommunications Authority, to remove the violation or to compel the Lessor to remove it within a specific period determined by the Chairman of the Disputes Committee in his decision, as the case may be, as a temporary measure until the Disputes Committee decides on the request definitively. The government entities and other concerned authorities must execute the order issued by the Chairman of the Disputes Committee as soon as possible. In the event the violation is not removed within the period specified in the order of the Chairman of the Disputes Committee for any reason whatsoever, the Chairman of the Disputes Committee may allow the Lessee to remove the violation by any alternative means approved by the Chairman of the Disputes Committee, if possible, or refer the matter to the Disputes Committee to issue an urgent decision including the following:
(a) Imposing a fine on the Lessor of not less than five thousand (5,000) Dirhams and not exceeding twenty thousand (20,000) Dirhams, as the Disputes Committee may deem appropriate.
(b) Compelling the Lessor to compensate the Lessee for all damage sustained due to the violation, or refunding any amounts incurred by the Lessee to remove the violation, if any, and failing that, deducting any amounts decided by the Disputes Committee from the Rent Amount due to the Lessor for the Leased Property, as the Disputes Committee may deem appropriate.

7(5) If the Leased Property is destroyed during the lease term, whether totally or partially, the Lessee may terminate the Lease Contract. The Lessee may not request compensation if the destruction is due to a cause beyond the Lessor's control, such as cases of force majeure like wars, earthquakes, floods, and other natural disasters.

7(6) If a material defect appears in the Leased Property that prevents the Lessee from utilizing it fully, and such defect was not known to the Lessee at the time of concluding the Lease Contract, the Lessee may request the Disputes Committee to reduce the Rent Amount reasonably. In the event the Lessee actually incurs any loss or damage as a result of such defect, the Disputes Committee may, upon the Lessee's request, judge in his favor for reasonable compensation as the Disputes Committee may deem appropriate in the concerned circumstances.

Article_8.title: Maintenance of the Leased Property
Article_8.content:
8(1) The Lessor must perform necessary repairs and restorations in the Leased Property during the lease term, and must perform, at least once every three (3) continuous years, the necessary maintenance works that are customarily the Lessor's responsibility in the Emirate to keep the Leased Property fit for utilization in accordance with its purpose and, as much as possible, in a condition approximating the condition in which the Lessee received it at the time of concluding the Lease Contract, or generally, to enable the Lessee to obtain the intended benefit from the Leased Property reasonably.

8(2) The Lessor must repair any defect occurring in the Leased Property that materially affects obtaining the full benefit thereof. If he fails to do so, the Lessee may request the Disputes Committee to issue a decision compelling the Lessor to repair the concerned defect. If the defect relates to the structure of the building or the roof, or if its repair is urgent and cannot be delayed, the Lessee may submit an urgent request to the Chairman of the Disputes Committee to compel the Lessor to repair the concerned defect. The Chairman of the Disputes Committee must treat the request as an urgent order and decide on it, on behalf of the Disputes Committee, in the shortest possible time, and ensure regarding it either obtaining a written undertaking from the Lessor to repair the concerned defect within a period specified in the said undertaking, or failing that, presenting the matter to the Disputes Committee as an urgent matter to issue a decision by the Committee giving permission to the Lessee to repair the defect through a third party determined by the Disputes Committee, with recourse against the Lessor for all that the Lessee spent in repairing the concerned defect, or deducting the value of said repairs from the current or future rent of the concerned property, or extending the lease term by the value of the concerned repairs, or reducing the Rent Amount for the duration of the decrease or loss of benefit that the Lessee was forced to endure, all as the Disputes Committee deems appropriate.

8(3) The Lessee may not prevent the Lessor from performing necessary works for the maintenance of the Leased Property whenever the Lessor wishes to do so, provided that the performance of such works does not lead to preventing the Lessee from utilizing the Leased Property reasonably. If the performance of maintenance results in preventing the Lessee from utilizing the property, the Lessee may request the Disputes Committee to judge in his favor for compensation equal to the damage incurred and the loss of his utilization of the Leased Property during the period of its maintenance by the Lessor.

Article_9.title: Lessee's Preservation of the Leased Property
Article_9.content:
9(1) The Lessee must preserve the Leased Property as an ordinary person preserves his own property. He must, in particular, perform all general cleaning works and simple maintenance necessary for utilizing the Leased Property in accordance with its purpose, which are customarily the Lessee's responsibility in the Emirate. The Lessee guarantees any shortage, damage, or loss to the Leased Property resulting from his negligence or transgression, unless it is proven by reasonable evidence that such shortage, damage, or loss arose from a cause beyond the Lessee's control. If the Lessee creates any planting, fixed decoration works, or other improvements in the Leased Property, he is committed to leaving them without compensation upon the end of the lease term unless the Lessor agrees otherwise.

9(2) The Lessee must return the Leased Property to the Lessor in the condition it was in at the beginning of the Lease Contract term, except for damage resulting from familiar use or reasonable use of the Leased Property or damage arising from a cause beyond the Lessee's control. If the Lessee received the Leased Property without a statement of its condition, it is presumed that the Lessee received it in good condition unless evidence is established to the contrary.

9(3) The Lessee may not perform any act leading to the vandalism of the Leased Property, damaging it, or decreasing its value. If the Lessee does so, the Lessor may, at any time, request the Disputes Committee to terminate the contract and guarantee the damage he sustained to the extent the Disputes Committee deems appropriate.

9(4) The Lessee may not assign possession of the property, or sublease it, in whole or in part, except with the Lessor's written approval. Notwithstanding the foregoing, if the Leased Property is a commercial place or a factory, and necessity requires the Lessee to sell that commercial place or factory accompanied by its material and intangible elements, then the Lease Contract applicable at that time may continue until the expiry of its term without the Lessor's permission, provided that in this case:
(a) The Lessor is notified of the original Lessee's assignment of the Leased Property, in whole or in part, to the Sub-lessee until the end of the contract term applicable at that time;
(b) The assignee Lessee provides the Lessor with sufficient guarantee to execute the original Lease Contract with the same terms and conditions; and
(c) The Lessor does not suffer grave damage as a result of such assignment. The Lessor's loss of the potential increase in the new Rent Amount is not considered grave damage within the meaning intended in this paragraph.

9(5) In the case of subleasing without the Lessor's written permission, the original Lessee remains, in all cases, responsible towards the Lessor for all the Lessee's obligations mentioned in the original Lease Contract. However, the Lessor may collect the Rent Amount directly from the Sub-lessee, and has the right to conclude a new Lease Contract with the Sub-lessee. In the event of concluding such new contract and attesting it properly, the original Lessee is then discharged towards the Lessor regarding all Lessee obligations mentioned in the original Lease Contract.

9(6) Unless there is an explicit provision in the Lease Contract to the contrary, the Lessee is obligated to pay the price of his consumption of water, electricity, gas, sewage fees, telephone, internet network, fees for shared services and the building in which the Leased Property is located, and other benefits related to the use of the Leased Property.

Article_10.title: Additional Constructions, Repairs, and Improvements
Article_10.content:
10(1) If the Lessee wishes to make any additional constructions in the Leased Property or any repairs or maintenance works necessary for the benefit of the Leased Property, he must obtain written permission from the Lessor before performing those additions, repairs, or maintenance. Failing that:
(a) The Lessee may not recover the value of what he spent to create those additional constructions, repairs, or necessary maintenance from the Lessor; and
(b) Unless the Lessor agrees in writing otherwise, the Lessee must, upon expiry of the lease term, return the Leased Property to the condition it was in at the time of concluding the Lease Contract. In the event of the Lessee's failure to do so, he must compensate the Lessor as the Disputes Committee may deem appropriate.

10(2) If the works performed by the Lessee in the Leased Property are in the nature of improvements or decoration works, or if the Lessee performed them for purposes personal to him or for his private benefit or for the benefit of his business, the Lessee may not recover the value of what he spent from the Lessor even in the case of subsequent termination of the contract by the Lessor, unless the parties have agreed in writing in the Lease Contract or in a subsequent written agreement otherwise.

Article_11.title: Trespass by Third Parties
Article_11.content:
11(1) If a significant decrease in the utilization of the Leased Property occurs as a result of trespass by a government entity or another person having a legal right over the Leased Property, the Lessee may request the Disputes Committee to terminate the Lease Contract or reduce the Rent Amount as the Disputes Committee may deem appropriate. The Disputes Committee may sentence the Lessor to compensate the Lessee if it is confirmed to it that the act of the government entity or the other person referred to above was done at the request of the Lessor or for a reason for which the Lessor is responsible.

11(2) The Lessor is not obligated to compensate the Lessee for physical trespass committed by a person without legitimate justification, but he must assist the Lessee positively to enable him to file a lawsuit, whether individually or jointly with the Lessor, before the competent court to claim compensation from the trespasser for the damage sustained by the Lessee due to such trespass without legitimate justification.

Article_12.title: Cases in Which Eviction of the Leased Property is Permitted
Article_12.content:
12(1) The Lessor may not request—even upon expiry of the lease term—the eviction of the Lessee from the Leased Property except for one of the following reasons:
(a) If the Lessee refuses to sign the new Lease Contract presented to him by the Lessor during the last month from the expiry date of the original Lease Contract or from the expiry date of any extension period thereof, unless the Lessee's refusal is due to an increase in the Rent Amount in a manner contrary to the increase prescribed under the provisions of this Decree.
(b) If the Lessee fails to pay the Rent Amount, or pay any installment thereof, within a maximum period of two (2) weeks from its due date, without an excuse accepted by the Disputes Committee. However, in the event the Lessor refuses to receive the Rent Amount or the agreed installment thereof in the contract, then the Lessee may deposit the Rent Amount or the concerned installment thereof with the Rapporteur of the Disputes Committee within a time not exceeding three (3) weeks from its due date. Such deposit shall be made without fees or other expenses pursuant to a petition order signed by the head of any chamber of the Disputes Committee. The deposit receipt duly issued by the Rapporteur of the Disputes Committee shall be considered a legal document discharging the Lessee from paying the Rent Amount or the due installment thereof within the limits of the deposited amount. The Rapporteur of the Disputes Committee must hand over the amount deposited with him to the Lessor within a maximum period of two (2) weeks after payment of the prescribed fees.
(c) If the Lessee fails to perform any obligation imposed on him by this Decree or any condition of the Lease Contract (other than conditions related to payment of the Rent Amount) within a period not exceeding three (3) weeks after the date of his receipt of a written request from the Lessor requesting him to perform that obligation or condition, unless the Lessee's non-performance of the concerned obligation or condition is due to a legitimate excuse approved by the Disputes Committee.
(d) If the Leased Property sustains grave damage as a result of a deliberate act by the Lessee, or as a result of his negligence in taking necessary caution or care, or due to his enabling any other person to cause damage to the Leased Property.
(e) If the Lessee leaves the Leased Property vacant for a continuous period of four (4) months and such leaving results in tangible damage to the Leased Property, the Disputes Committee may order the Lessee to vacate even if it is proven that he previously paid the Rent Amount due for the said four (4) months period.
(f) If the Lessee uses the Leased Property, or allows others to use it, for purposes contrary to the law or incompatible with public morals or the traditions and customs observed by residents in the area where the Leased Property is located, or in a manner that actually harms the Lessor's financial interests.
(g) If the Lessor presents evidence to the Disputes Committee that convinces the Disputes Committee of the Lessor's need to use the Leased Property for himself or for any of his family members of the first and second degrees (parents, spouse, children, siblings, paternal uncles, maternal uncles). For the lawsuit to be accepted in this case, it is required that the Lessor notifies the Lessee in writing of his need to use the Leased Property at least three months prior to the date of filing the lawsuit.
(h) If it is proven that the Lessee subleased the Leased Property or part thereof or assigned its possession to a third party without the owner's permission and in violation of the provisions of the Lease Contract and the provisions of this Decree. In this case, the Disputes Committee may also judge to evict the Sub-lessee while preserving his right to claim compensation from the original Lessee.
(i) If the Lessor desires to demolish the Leased Property because it is dilapidated, or because it has exceeded its operational lifespan, or to perform substantial and complete maintenance of the Leased Property to improve its value or to change the purpose of its use in a way that materially affects its previous status. For a judgment to evict the Leased Property in this case, it is required:
(1) That the Lessor presents to the Disputes Committee an official certificate issued by the Municipality confirming that the demolition or the concerned maintenance, improvement, and change works are necessary for the Leased Property or that it is consistent with the real estate development plan in the area where the Leased Property is located; and
(2) That the Lessor obtains the preliminary permission or necessary license from the Municipality to perform the demolition or the required maintenance, improvement, or change works; and
(3) That the Lessor requests the Lessee to vacate the Leased Property by a written notice duly delivered to the Lessee three (3) months prior to the date of issuance of the preliminary permission or license from the Municipality to perform the demolition or the required maintenance, improvement, or change works.
(4) That the Lessor executes a written undertaking committing to the provisions of Article (13) of this Decree.
(j) If a government entity decides that public interest requires the eviction of a property owned by it or under its disposal from its Lessee, and such government entity sends a written notice to the Lessee for a period of not less than three months prior to the date scheduled for eviction, including the justifications and reasons for the eviction decision based on public interest requirements. In this case, the Disputes Committee may, upon the Lessee's request, reject the decision of the concerned government entity due to the absence of public interest or, otherwise, grant the Lessee a grace period and order his continuation in possession of the Leased Property for a maximum period of six (6) months from the date of the Disputes Committee's decision. It may also judge compensation for the Lessee to redress any actual damage sustained by him as a direct result of his eviction under the provisions of this Article, as the Disputes Committee may deem appropriate and fair.

12(2) A Lessee of a commercial, industrial, or professional property may request the Disputes Committee to terminate the Lease Contract after concluding it with him due to the refusal of the competent licensing authorities to grant him the required license to practice the activity required to be practiced in the Leased Property. In this case, the Disputes Committee may judge to terminate the contract provided the Lessee is obligated to pay compensation to the Lessor equivalent to the Rent Amount prescribed for three months.

12(3) A Lessee of a property leased for residential purposes may request the Lessor to terminate the Lease Contract during its valid term for any reasonable reason or justification, by means of a written notice to the Lessor the duration of which is not less than one month. In this case, the Disputes Committee must terminate the contract while obligating the Lessee to pay compensation to the Lessor equivalent to the Rent Amount prescribed for two months, or equivalent to the Rent Amount prescribed for three months in the event of the Lessee's failure to send the aforementioned written notice to the Lessor.

Article_13.title: Lessee's Right to Return to the Property After Eviction or Compensation
Article_13.content: If the Lessee vacates the Leased Property in accordance with a decision issued by the Disputes Committee pursuant to the provisions of Article 12(i) above, the Lessor must execute what the eviction was requested for within the period determined by the Disputes Committee in its eviction decision issued pursuant to Article (12(i)) above, and undertake to the Disputes Committee in writing to occupy the Leased Property himself or by his concerned relative for a period of not less than one full year. If the Lessor fails to execute such undertaking for any reason whatsoever, or if it is subsequently proven that the Lessor's request to evict the property pursuant to Article (12(g) or 12(i)) was in bad faith or based on incorrect data, then the Disputes Committee may, upon a subsequent request from the Lessee, order the return of the Lessee to the property he vacated and/or obligate the Lessor to compensate the Lessee for any loss and damage he sustained as a result of the eviction. It is required for granting the Lessee's request to return him to the Leased Property or for compensation that he has committed to executing the eviction judgment pursuant to Article (12(i)) within two months from the date of its issuance.

Article_14.title: Opening and Inventorying the Leased Property in the Absence of the Lessee
Article_14.content:
14(1) If the lease term of the Leased Property expires without the Lessee renewing it, and evidence is available that he left the Leased Property locked without handing it over to the Lessor, and his place of residence in the State is currently unknown, then the Lessor may request the Disputes Committee to direct an advertisement to the Lessee ordering him to appear before it on a date specified in the advertisement to consider the Lessor's request for eviction. The advertisement shall be published in Arabic in one of the local newspapers at the Lessor's expense, and a copy of the advertisement shall be posted on the door of the Leased Property or in a prominent place thereon.

14(2) If the Lessee appears on the date specified in the advertisement or during the advertisement period and claims the Lessor has no right to evict him from the Leased Property, the Disputes Committee must consider the dispute for eviction of the Leased Property according to the provisions of Article (12) of this Decree.

14(3) If the period granted to the Lessee in the advertisement expires and the Lessee does not appear, the Disputes Committee may form a temporary committee constituted, in each case separately, of a representative of the Municipality, a representative of the Police, and a representative of the Lessor, and authorize the said temporary committee to open the Leased Property in the absence of the Lessee, inventory any valuable properties found inside it, and hand over those properties—if any—to the Lessor to keep as a trust with him or with any other entity the Disputes Committee deems appropriate. Then the property shall be handed over to the Lessor and a detailed report thereof shall be organized and signed by the three members of the temporary committee.

14(4) As an exception to the general rules regarding the execution of judgments in civil lawsuits, the Execution Judge may, on his own motion or pursuant to a request from the Lessor, order the sale of any rapidly perishable properties found inside the Leased Property, or the sale of valuable properties referred to in Clause (14(3)) above, and allocate the proceeds from the sale to pay the outstanding Rent Amount, if any, and to pay any other expenses as he may deem appropriate, and keep the remainder of the sale proceeds—if any—with the Rapporteur of the Disputes Committee for a maximum period of forty-five (45) days, after which such proceeds shall be allocated for any purpose the Execution Judge deems appropriate.

14(5) The handover of the property to the Lessor in the manner mentioned in Paragraph 14(3) above does not affect the Lessee's right to subsequently request the Disputes Committee to obligate the Lessor to compensate the Lessee for damages actually incurred if it is subsequently proven that the Lessor's action was in bad faith or that the data upon which the Lessor relied in his request to the Disputes Committee to open the Leased Property in the Lessee's absence and regain possession for the Lessor, or upon which he relied in his request to sell the properties found in the Leased Property, were incorrect and in bad faith.

Article_15.title: The Disputes Committee
Article_15.content:
15(1) The Disputes Committee shall be formed by an Amiri Decree issued by the Crown Prince of Ajman after consultation with the Chairman of the Municipality Department. The judges and members of the Disputes Committee shall continue to occupy their positions in the chambers of the said Committee until they are replaced, in whole or in part, by a subsequent Amiri Decree issued by the Crown Prince of Ajman. The judges and members of the Committee shall be granted remunerations decided by the Crown Prince of the Emirate of Ajman from time to time as he may deem appropriate.

15(2) The Disputes Committee shall perform its competencies mentioned in Article (16) of this Decree through chambers, each chamber consisting of a presidency by a judge deputized from the Ministry of Justice in addition to three members with expertise and broad knowledge in the field of real estate development, leasing, and management in the Emirate of Ajman. The Chairman of the Disputes Committee shall distribute the Committee members and assign them among the Committee chambers and distribute tenancy dispute lawsuits among the Committee chambers equally and according to the priority of their registration and payment of fees thereon.

15(3) Unless the context of the text requires a different meaning, any reference in this Decree to "The Disputes Committee" shall be read and interpreted as a reference also to each one of the chambers of the Disputes Committee separately. Accordingly, each chamber of the Disputes Committee shall be legally competent to perform the competencies assigned to the Disputes Committee under the provisions of this Decree, and in particular, the tasks of hearing and deciding, finally and decisively, tenancy disputes presented before it as if the concerned dispute is being heard before, and finally decided by, the Disputes Committee meeting with its full panel of judges and membership.

15(4) Each chamber of the Disputes Committee shall convene on the day specified for it in the Executive Regulations and in the place designated for it by the Municipality. The session of any chamber of the Disputes Committee may not convene except in the presence of the Judge/Chairman of the concerned chamber in addition to at least two members of the concerned chamber. Unless agreed amicably among the heads of the Committee chambers otherwise, tenancy dispute lawsuits shall be distributed among the chambers of the Disputes Committee equally and according to the priority of their registration and payment of fees thereon.

15(5) Each chamber of the Disputes Committee shall take its decisions unanimously or by a simple majority of those present. If opinions are equal regarding the issuance of a decision by any chamber, the side containing the Chairman of the concerned chamber shall prevail.

15(6) The Chairman of each chamber of the Disputes Committee is competent to sign decisions issued by his chamber, including all correspondence related to the execution of those decisions, whether through the Temporary Execution Committee referred to in Article (18(2)) of this Decree or through the Execution Judge. The Chairman of the Disputes Committee is competent to sign all administrative decisions and all correspondence issued by the Disputes Committee to official entities. He may authorize whomever he wishes from among the judges and members of the Disputes Committee to sign any correspondence on behalf of the Disputes Committee.

Article_16.title: Competencies of the Disputes Committee
Article_16.content:
16(1) Subject to the provisions of Articles (3(2)) and (16(2)) of this Decree, the Disputes Committee alone, to the exclusion of others, is competent with the authority to hear and decide, finally and decisively, all types of disputes and counter-disputes arising from or due to the contractual relationship between a Lessor and a Lessee of any real estate in the Emirate of Ajman subject to the provisions of this Decree. Without prejudice to the generality of this text, the Disputes Committee is competent to hear and decide, finally and decisively, tenancy disputes related to the following:
(a) The Lessee's failure to pay the Rent Amount agreed upon in the Lease Contract.
(b) A request to increase the Rent Amount by the Lessor or a request to reduce it by the Lessee.
(c) Determining the "Rent of Similar" for the Leased Property.
(d) Eviction of the Leased Property for one of the reasons listed in Article (12) of this Decree.
(e) The Lessor's failure to maintain the Leased Property or to provide the guarantees of the Leased Property in accordance with the provisions of this Decree or accordance with the conditions of the Lease Contract.
(f) The Lessee's failure to perform his obligations regarding the maintenance and preservation of the Leased Property in accordance with the provisions of this Decree or accordance with the conditions of the Lease Contract.
(g) A claim by either party to the Lease Contract for compensation for any damage incurred as a result of the other party's breach of any provision of this Decree or any condition of the Lease Contract without legitimate excuse.
(h) Any dispute related to proving the legitimacy or validity of the Lease Contract or the interpretation or application of any condition of the Lease Contract.
(i) Any other dispute the Disputes Committee deems to fall within its jurisdiction.
(j) Deciding on any petition for review of a decision issued by the Disputes Committee.

16(2) Each Chairman of a chamber in the Disputes Committee shall have full powers and authorities to take any precautionary, urgent, temporary, or incidental measures connected to any dispute presented before the Disputes Committee, including taking any ordinary or urgent measures as may be necessary to execute any decision issued by the Disputes Committee in accordance with the provisions of this Decree. This includes, in particular, the authorities to issue decisions to seize, hand over, or sell any movables or other valuable items or ban the convicted person from traveling outside the State unless there are legal reasons preventing execution. All competent authorities and government entities in the Emirate must execute the decisions of the Disputes Committee and carry out their requirements, even compulsorily, whenever requested by the Execution Judge.

16(3) Notwithstanding what is stated in Article (16(1)) and Article (16(2)) above, if the Disputes Committee, or its Chairman individually, deems after perusing the statement of claim that the facts of the concerned lawsuit relate to matters outside the scope of the tenancy relationship, such as proving ownership of the Leased Property, or the transfer of such ownership via inheritance or otherwise to another person other than the owner of the Leased Property mentioned in the Lease Contract, or that the Leased Property is subject to a real estate mortgage affecting the Lessee's possession thereof or his full utilization thereof, or if one of the parties claims the existence of forgery in the Lease Contract or documents connected thereto or matters similar thereto which require judicial investigation by the Public Prosecution or by a competent court, or the availability of special technical expertise unavailable to the Disputes Committee, then the Disputes Committee, or its Chairman individually, may issue a decision of lack of specific jurisdiction of the Disputes Committee to hear the dispute while directing the litigants to refer their dispute to the Public Prosecution or the competent court, as the case may be.

16(4) The Disputes Committee may not hear a tenancy dispute, nor may any decision issued by it in a tenancy dispute be executed, except after payment of the fees determined by the Municipality from time to time. The Disputes Committee and the Execution Judge, as the case may be, may, based on objective and sufficient reasons, defer payment of part of the said fees, not exceeding half of the prescribed fees, provided the Rapporteur of the Disputes Committee receives a post-dated bank check for the value of the deferred fees before commencing the hearing of the lawsuit or the execution of the Disputes Committee's decision therein, as the case may be. The Disputes Committee may order, within its final decision in the dispute, compensation for the party in whose favor the Committee's decision was issued for all or any part of the said fees, with or without any other expenses, as the Disputes Committee may deem appropriate.

Article_17.title: Procedures for Tenancy Disputes
Article_17.content:
17(1) The plaintiff in any tenancy dispute must attach the original copy or a true copy of the Lease Contract from which the dispute arose, provided that such contract is attested by the Municipality. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Disputes Committee must hear the lawsuit if the plaintiff pays the prescribed fees and/or fines for not drawing up the Lease Contract or neglecting to attest it, and attaches with the statement of claim the official certificate regarding the lease of the concerned property issued by the Municipality in accordance with the provisions of Article 4(4) of the Decree.

17(2) Tenancy disputes shall be treated as civil lawsuits of an urgent nature. In order to provide swift justice, the Disputes Committee may, when hearing such disputes, apply the rules of natural justice and the provisions of Islamic Sharia without being bound by the pleading procedures applicable in the State's courts. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Disputes Committee must ensure summoning the litigants to appear before it and enabling them to present their documents and hear their witnesses and aspects of defense. Subject to what is stated in this Article, no procedure of the Disputes Committee shall be void unless the law explicitly stipulates its nullity.

17(3) No Chairman of a chamber in the Disputes Committee or any member thereof may participate in hearing and deciding any dispute if he has a direct interest therein or is related to one of the parties therein by blood or marriage up to the fourth degree, or is a partner to one of the parties therein or a guardian over him. In all cases, the concerned Chairman of the chamber or member must recuse himself from the session in which the concerned dispute is heard.

17(4) The Disputes Committee may seek the opinion of any engineer, accountant, or other expert whenever it deems it necessary to decide on any matter presented before it. It may administer the oath to any party, expert, or witness in any dispute before it whenever the Disputes Committee deems it necessary.

Article_18.title: Authority and Execution of Disputes Committee Decisions
Article_18.content:
18(1) If the Lessor and Lessee explicitly agree in the Lease Contract to refer any dispute between them regarding the legitimacy, interpretation, or application of that contract for final and decisive decision by the Disputes Committee, then neither party to the concerned Lease Contract may file a lawsuit before the judicial courts regarding the subject matter of the dispute between them. The decision issued by the Disputes Committee in the dispute presented before it shall be a final and conclusive decision in the concerned dispute, and such decision may not be appealed by any method of appeal against judgments.

18(2) The decision issued by any chamber of the Disputes Committee shall be executed pursuant to an order signed by the Chairman of the chamber that issued the decision. Such execution shall take place, after payment of the prescribed execution fees, within ten (10) days from the date of issuance of the concerned decision and by means of a Temporary Execution Committee formed, in each case separately, by the Chairman of the concerned chamber, from representatives of the Disputes Committee, the Municipality, and Ajman Police, in addition to any other person or persons whose presence is required during the execution of the concerned decision as the Chairman of the concerned chamber may deem appropriate. Notwithstanding the foregoing:
(a) If the Chairman of the concerned chamber sees, for any objective reasons he is convinced of, the impossibility of executing the concerned decision by the aforementioned Temporary Execution Committee and the necessity of executing the concerned decision directly through the Execution Judge; or
(b) If it is impossible for any reason whatsoever to execute the concerned decision by the aforementioned Temporary Execution Committee within ten (10) days from the date of its issuance;
Then, in either of the mentioned cases, the Chairman of the concerned chamber may, upon the request of any interested party in executing the concerned decision and after payment of prescribed fees, refer the decision of the Disputes Committee for execution through the Execution Judge.

18(3) As an exception to the general rules in executing judgments in civil lawsuits, the Execution Judge must, within a period not exceeding three (3) working days after receiving the decision of the Disputes Committee referred to him in accordance with the provisions of Article (18(2)) above, affix the executive formula to the concerned Disputes Committee decision and order it to be included with expedited enforcement. The execution shall take place without the need to review the components of the decision by the Execution Judge and within a maximum period of twenty-one (21) days from the date of the Execution Judge's receipt of the concerned decision unless there is a legal impediment preventing such. The person against whom execution is sought must be notified of the order or orders of the Execution Judge issued against him, accompanied by a copy of the execution petition, preserving the right of the person against whom execution is sought to grieve against the Execution Judge's order within ten (10) days from the date of his notification thereof. The grievance shall be filed to the Execution Judge and must be written and substantiated. The Execution Judge's decision in that grievance, and in all other execution disputes, shall be final and conclusive.

18(4) As an exception to the general rules in correcting civil judgments, the Execution Judge may, upon receiving the execution documents pursuant to Article (18(2)) above, perform individually on his own motion or upon the request of any interested person, the correction of any mathematical or clerical errors appearing in the decision of the Disputes Committee, or add any new phrase to the text of the decision of the Disputes Committee exclusively for the purpose of clarifying the content of the concerned Disputes Committee decision more fully and better to lead to its execution.

Article_19.title: Petition for Review of the Disputes Committee Decision
Article_19.content:
19(1) Notwithstanding the provisions of Article (18) above, the person against whom a decision of the Disputes Committee is issued may submit, within a period not exceeding fifteen (15) days from the date of issuance of the concerned decision, a written petition to the Chairman of the Disputes Committee petitioning for a review of the concerned decision based on the existence of one or more of the following reasons:
(a) That the petitioner was not notified legally or was not properly represented during the hearing of the concerned dispute or was deprived of presenting his documents and hearing his witnesses and defense in the tenancy lawsuit.
(b) If the decision includes a judgment on a matter outside the jurisdiction of the Disputes Committee.
(c) If fraud occurred from the adversary that influenced the decisions of the Disputes Committee.
(d) If the decision was built on forged papers or false testimony or malicious testimony or any other legally inadmissible testimony.
(e) If the operative part of the Disputes Committee's decision is clearly contradictory.
(f) If the Chairman of the chamber that issued the concerned decision or one of its members was legally unfit to hear the lawsuit due to the existence of a commercial partnership or kinship or marriage relationship between him and the adversary in whose favor the decision of the Disputes Committee was issued.
(g) If the litigation was extinguished or expired by lapse of time.
(h) If it is proven that the petitioner for review has new legal evidence or attached with his petition new evidence or a new document, and such new evidence or new document, as the case may be, would substantially change the point of view in the dispute.

19(2) In all cases, the petition for review may not be registered if its petition is not accompanied by proof of payment by the petitioner of the fees prescribed for registering the petition in addition to depositing a security of two thousand (2,000) Dirhams, which shall be returned to him if judgment is issued accepting his petition, and said security shall be confiscated if the Disputes Committee rules not to accept the petition in form or rejects its subject.

19(3) The Chairman of the Disputes Committee must refer the petition to a chamber other than the chamber that issued the judgment. The decision in the petition shall be issued by a chamber presided over by a judge and attended by not less than three (3) of its members, to decide on the request for review filed before it pursuant to Article 19(1) above. In the event of equality of opinions regarding the Committee's decision in the petition, the side containing the Chairman of the Committee shall prevail. The decision issued by the Committee regarding the petition shall be final and not subject to appeal by any legal methods of appeal.

Article_20.title: Local Orders and Other Decisions
Article_20.content:
For the purposes of executing this Law, the Chairman of the Municipality may, after consultation with the Chairman of the Disputes Committee, issue any local orders or other decisions regarding the following matters:
(a) The format of the standard Lease Contract approved by the Municipality for use in leasing real estate for residential, commercial, industrial, or other purposes.
(b) The system for attesting lease contracts of various types.

Article_21.title: Executive Regulations and Bylaws
Article_21.content:
(a) The Crown Prince of the Emirate shall, after consultation with the Chairman of the Municipality and the Chairman of the Disputes Committee, issue the Executive Regulations and Bylaws for this Decree, which must include, in particular, the following: The internal regulations of the Disputes Committee, which include conditions for registering a tenancy dispute, hearing and deciding on temporary and urgent requests submitted by litigants, rules for notifying litigants, how to hear the tenancy dispute and decide on it urgently, procedures to be followed to ensure the execution of Disputes Committee decisions through swift and urgent procedures, and procedures for submitting petitions for review of Disputes Committee decisions and how to decide on them within the period specified in this Decree.
(b) The list of fees to be paid for attesting real estate lease contracts of various types.
(c) The list of fees for tenancy disputes in Ajman, which must include, without limitation, fees for registering and renewing tenancy disputes, fees for temporary and urgent requests, fees for approving powers of attorney to appear before the Committee, fees for requests to delegate experts, fees for inspection reports of the Leased Property, fees for notifying the adversary including notification by publication in daily newspapers, fees for depositing the key of the Leased Property, requests to intervene a litigant during the course of the lawsuit, requests for the Lessor to receive the Rent Amount from the Disputes Committee trust, requests to execute judgments issued by the Committee including opening the Leased Property during the Lessee's absence and handing it over to the owner, fees for requests for petition to review the decision of the Disputes Committee, and requests to obtain photocopies of dispute papers or to obtain any certificate from the Disputes Committee or from services provided by the Disputes Committee to beneficiaries from the Municipality and other service fees.
(d) The list of violations of real estate tenancy regulations in the Emirate of Ajman and the fines prescribed upon their commission.

Article_22.title: Repeal of Amiri Decree No. (3) of 2009 and Its Amendments
Article_22.content: As of the effective date of this Decree, Amiri Decree No. (3) of 2009 and all amendments introduced to it by Amiri Decrees No. (8) of 2014 and No. (3) of 2016 shall be repealed, without prejudice to the validity of the effectiveness of any decisions issued or procedures taken pursuant to the provisions of the three mentioned Amiri Decrees until the date of their repeal under the provisions of this Article. Notwithstanding the mentioned repeal, all lease contracts valid on the effective date of this Amiri Decree shall continue to be valid and legally effective until they are amended or renewed in accordance with the provisions of this Decree.

Article_23.title: Execution, Publication, and Circulation of the Decree
Article_23.content: This Decree shall be published in the Official Gazette of the Emirate and shall be circulated as widely as possible to all entities concerned with its execution, each within its jurisdiction.
